title: 107_s2710
content: The Act titled "Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002" provides a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under SEC. 45G of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002 offers a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit is based on the amount paid by the taxpayer during the taxable year for qualified employee health insurance expenses, with the applicable percentage determined by the average annual rate of wages of qualified employees. The Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002 offers a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit amount is determined by specific percentages and formulas based on the average annual rate of wages and the number of qualified employees. For employers with not more than 50 qualified employees and an average annual rate of wages not exceeding $30,000, the applicable percentage shall not be less than 5 percent. The per-employee dollar limitation for qualified employee health insurance expenses is $2,000 for self-only coverage. The credit amount is determined by specific percentages and formulas based on the average annual rate of wages and the number of qualified employees. The per-employee dollar limitation for qualified employee health insurance expenses is $2,000 for self-only coverage and $5,000 for family coverage. An employer is considered eligible if they employed an average of the specified number of employees on business days during the taxable year. The Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002 provides a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit amount is determined by specific percentages and formulas based on the average annual rate of wages and the number of qualified employees. The determination of qualified employees is based on the average number of employees on business days during the preceding calendar years, with specific considerations for employers not in existence in the preceding year. The term 'qualified employee health insurance expenses' refers to employer payments for health insurance coverage provided to at least 50% of qualified employees, excluding amounts paid under salary reduction arrangements. 'Health insurance coverage' is defined as per section 9832(b)(1), with exceptions. The term 'qualified employee' refers to an employee who works more than 30 hours per week for the employer, excluding those eligible for certain health plans or benefits under the Social Security Act. The term 'employee' excludes certain individuals but includes leased employees under specific sections of various codes and medical care programs. The term 'wages' is defined without dollar limitations, and rules similar to section 52 apply. No double benefits are allowed for qualified employee health insurance expenses. The credit is part of the general business credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The employee health insurance expenses credit under section 45G cannot be carried back before January 1, 2003. The amendments made by this section apply to small business employee health insurance expenses for coverage established after the enactment of this Act, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002.
